snippet: General Motors said on Wednesday that it had received reports of a safety defect in its cars as early as 2001 — three years earlier than previously disclosed.
abstract: General Motors acknowledges that it had received reports as early as 2001, three years earlier than previously disclosed, of a safety defect in its cars that the company has now linked to 12 deaths and at least 31 accidents; expanded chronology, part of filing with federal safety regulators concerning 1.6 million-car recall, also identifies two additional nonfatal crashes related to problem.
lead_paragraph: General Motors said on Wednesday that it had received reports of a safety defect in its cars as early as 2001 — three years earlier than previously disclosed.

headline.main: G.M. Reveals It Was Told of Ignition Defect in ’01
headline.print_headline: G.M. Reveals It Was Told of Ignition Defect in ’01
